documents.title: Catch up with Kesha and Mona
documents.content: Catch up with Kesha and Mona  decision, scope change, process confusion, complaint, positive feedback The meeting was called to inform Monaliza and Kesha that their roles are being terminated due to client-driven organizational restructuring, not performance issues. The team reassured them that they will be prioritized for reassignment to other clients and provided guidance on next steps for final pay and potential redeployment. Both VAs expressed disappointment but showed willingness to continue with the agency. Job loss due to client restructuring, Uncertainty about redeployment timeline, Emotional impact of sudden notice Clear communication that termination is not performance-based, Agency commitment to prioritize reassignment for affected VAs, Supportive and empathetic tone from management Communicate willingness of Monaliza and Kesha to be reassigned to the admin/recruitment team, Send formal documentation and quit claim instructions to VAs, Update VAs by next week regarding redeployment opportunities, Ensure finance processes final pay promptly upon completion of quit claim

The team reassured them that they will be prioritized for reassignment to other clients and provided guidance on next steps for final pay and potential redeployment. Both VAs expressed disappointment but showed willingness to continue with the agency.

documents.title: Outlier Discussion - 2025-11-10
documents.content: The team discussed recent health and weather disruptions, reviewed the status of VAs previously marked as at-risk, and evaluated the effectiveness of new engagement initiatives. Key feedback from VAs regarding role clarity and compensation was addressed, along with client concerns about over-reliance on AI and communication patterns. Action plans for ongoing check-ins, anonymous feedback reporting, and client follow-ups were outlined.
documents.summary: The team discussed recent health and weather disruptions, reviewed the status of VAs previously marked as at-risk, and evaluated the effectiveness of new engagement initiatives. Key feedback from VAs regarding role clarity and compensation was addressed, along with client concerns about over-reliance on AI and communication patterns. Action plans for ongoing check-ins, anonymous feedback reporting, and client follow-ups were outlined.
key_insights: Randomized, personalized check-ins improved VA engagement and responsiveness.
VAs are experiencing scope creep and role ambiguity, leading to compensation concerns.
Clients are increasingly concerned about over-reliance on AI tools and want more sense-checking and communication.
Anonymous feedback channels are more likely to surface honest concerns from VAs.
action_items: Continue randomized, engaging check-ins with VAs.
Draft and deliver an anonymous weekly feedback summary to the client (Atlas).
Monitor and report on AI usage among VAs as requested by the client.
Meet to finalize the weekly summary for Andrea.
Await client response on role alignment and compensation feedback before further action.
best_practices: Conducting welfare check-ins at random times with personalized questions to increase engagement.
Using anonymous feedback channels to elicit honest responses.
Avoiding repetitive questioning to prevent disengagement.
kpis_mentioned: VA engagement/response rate (improved to 100% for Atlas GTMs after new check-in strategy)
Check-in frequency (randomized, not just at shift start)

documents.title: Outlier Discussion - 2025-12-12
documents.content: The team discussed outlier VAs and clients ahead of the holiday season, focusing on performance concerns, part-time VAs seeking additional hours, and client requests for replacements. Strategies for improving communication, monitoring, and converting part-time VAs to full-time were considered, with attention to avoiding cannibalization of client requests.
documents.summary: The team discussed outlier VAs and clients ahead of the holiday season, focusing on performance concerns, part-time VAs seeking additional hours, and client requests for replacements. Strategies for improving communication, monitoring, and converting part-time VAs to full-time were considered, with attention to avoiding cannibalization of client requests.
key_insights: Part-time VAs are more likely to seek additional clients or hours, increasing churn risk if not addressed.
Direct communication channels (WhatsApp with disappearing messages) may improve responsiveness for remote VAs.
Client requests for replacements and multiple part-time VAs in one department can signal instability or unmet needs.
Pushing part-time VAs to full-time can reduce churn risk but must be balanced against cannibalizing new client requests.
action_items: Send follow-up emails to Nicole and Joyce regarding replacement proposals.
Monitor Atlas VAs with direct messages before and after shifts, switch to WhatsApp for communication.
Draft referral suggestion wording for clients with part-time VAs seeking more hours.
Pause full-time push for Triple A part-timers until new client requests are clarified.
Share WhatsApp numbers for VAs to improve communication.
Develop SOP for part-time to full-time conversion and referral process.
best_practices: Monitor VAs closely during shift using direct messaging.
Use WhatsApp with disappearing messages for secure, responsive communication.
Suggest full-time conversion for part-time VAs at milestone check-ins.
Frame additional hours as referral opportunities to clients rather than hard push.

documents.title: Outlier Discussion - 2025-11-15
documents.content: The team discussed their experiences during recent typhoons, including operational disruptions such as power outages and communication issues. They reviewed the resilience and contingency planning for the VA team, shared feedback about client relationships, and outlined plans for improved support and risk forecasting. The meeting also acknowledged individual contributions and recent personal challenges among team members.
documents.summary: The team discussed their experiences during recent typhoons, including operational disruptions such as power outages and communication issues. They reviewed the resilience and contingency planning for the VA team, shared feedback about client relationships, and outlined plans for improved support and risk forecasting. The meeting also acknowledged individual contributions and recent personal challenges among team members.
key_insights: Resilience and contingency planning are critical for VA teams during natural disasters.
Open, proactive feedback with clients (e.g., Atlas) improves partnership and retention.
Filtered but honest communication helps clients accept negative feedback constructively.
Having backup systems (e.g., Starlink, radios) is essential for business continuity.
action_items: Crissy to draft a contingency support plan for the VA team (including Starlink and radio options).
Monitor VAs who went offline during outage for ongoing risk signals.
Continue open feedback and forecasting conversations with Atlas and other clients.
Include Isaac in Starlink contingency program.
best_practices: Proactively communicating risk signals to clients and preparing replacements.
Using filtered but honest feedback to maintain client trust.
Implementing backup communication systems (Starlink, radios) for continuity.
Recognizing and supporting team members during personal and operational crises.

documents.title: Outlier Discussion - 2025-10-24
documents.content: The team discussed recent VA replacements and ongoing client concerns, focusing on high-risk VAs and clients with repeated turnover. Key updates included profiling and onboarding a new VA (Roma) for a critical client, addressing technical issues with another VA, and handling upcoming terminations. The group reviewed action plans, risk signals, and strategies for improving retention and client satisfaction.
documents.summary: The team discussed recent VA replacements and ongoing client concerns, focusing on high-risk VAs and clients with repeated turnover. Key updates included profiling and onboarding a new VA (Roma) for a critical client, addressing technical issues with another VA, and handling upcoming terminations. The group reviewed action plans, risk signals, and strategies for improving retention and client satisfaction.
key_insights: Reliability and attendance are prioritized for high-turnover clients over pure performance.
Technical issues are a leading indicator of potential VA churn.
Clients with a history of multiple replacements are less open to remediation and prefer immediate replacements.
Direct, transparent feedback and daily check-ins can help mitigate risk during onboarding.
action_items: Daily start and end-of-day check-ins with Roma during onboarding.
Training Jep on AI-powered email handling and SOP mirroring from Anne.
Follow up with Jericho to ensure laptop replacement and monitor technical issue resolution.
Proceed with Mona's replacement; interviews scheduled.
Catch up with Rochelle to prepare her for mentoring Roma.
best_practices: Pre-profiling VAs before pitching replacements to clients.
Daily start and end-of-day check-ins during onboarding for at-risk placements.
Mirroring best-performing VAs' SOPs to upskill others.
Clear, direct communication with both VAs and clients regarding expectations and feedback.

documents.title: Outlier Discussion - 2025-11-27
documents.content: The team discussed upcoming holiday schedules, onboarding and data protection procedures, and focused on an outlier VA case involving Dianara's resignation and extension. The group reviewed communication processes with clients, feedback loops, and check-in protocols for VAs, highlighting a potential risk with the client Jason due to delayed notification of Dianara's resignation.
documents.summary: The team discussed upcoming holiday schedules, onboarding and data protection procedures, and focused on an outlier VA case involving Dianara's resignation and extension. The group reviewed communication processes with clients, feedback loops, and check-in protocols for VAs, highlighting a potential risk with the client Jason due to delayed notification of Dianara's resignation.
key_insights: Delayed communication of VA resignation to client can create trust issues and risk client relationship.
Onboarding packets should include explicit data protection and confidentiality guidelines, signed by VAs.
Regular check-ins with VAs after onboarding are important for early detection of issues.
action_items: Publish and require signature on onboarding packet covering confidentiality and data protection.
Consider integrating confidentiality guidelines into PTO and attendance policy documents.
Prepare to address client concerns transparently if approached about resignation communication.
Louise to share feedback from recent Atlas meeting.
Shey to follow up with Wendy regarding confidentiality practices.
best_practices: Require VAs to sign onboarding packet covering confidentiality and data sharing.
Conduct informal and formal check-ins with VAs during first week to assess adjustment and address concerns.
Avoid sharing client-specific sensitive data in daily updates.

documents.title: Outlier Discussion - 2025-10-31
documents.content: The team discussed year-end party plans, VA engagement strategies, and improvements to offboarding and churn analysis processes. Key focus was on communication issues with VAs, implementing structured data tracking, and developing best practices for churn risk investigation. Several action items were agreed upon to enhance reporting and root cause analysis for VA offboarding.
documents.summary: The team discussed year-end party plans, VA engagement strategies, and improvements to offboarding and churn analysis processes. Key focus was on communication issues with VAs, implementing structured data tracking, and developing best practices for churn risk investigation. Several action items were agreed upon to enhance reporting and root cause analysis for VA offboarding.
key_insights: Non-responsiveness in daily check-ins is a strong churn risk for VAs.
Surprise client offboardings highlight need for better data tracking and root cause analysis.
Structured data collection (spreadsheets, checklists) can improve churn prediction and post-mortem analysis.
Exit interviews and multi-source data comparison are essential for understanding churn events.
action_items: Develop a standardized report/checklist for VA offboarding events.
Create agent file spreadsheets to track VA attendance, coaching sessions, and infractions.
Implement exit interviews and root cause investigations for both VA and client sides.
Organize VA data folders with onboarding and offboarding checklists.
Present supplier options for year-end party merchandise.
best_practices: Mark VAs as orange if they are non-responsive to informal check-ins.
Use multi-source data (client, VA, third-party) for churn root cause analysis.
Maintain agent files/spreadsheets for each VA to track key metrics and events.
Conduct exit interviews for both VA and client sides to compare perspectives.
kpis_mentioned: Number of coaching sessions per VA

documents.title: Suggestion: Jep - client_relationship
documents.content: Conduct a post-mortem review of the last 60 days of client communications to identify missed signals or warning signs. Schedule a transparency call with the client to clarify expectations for future offboarding and communication protocols.
documents.summary: Conduct a post-mortem review of the last 60 days of client communications to identify missed signals or warning signs. Schedule a transparency call with the client to clarify expectations for future offboarding and communication protocols.
documents.issues: Surprise cancellation and lack of transparency from client
documents.rationale: Surprise cancellations are a critical risk; past Outlier meetings show that post-mortems and transparency calls help rebuild trust and update detection patterns.
documents.stakeholder_notes: Good suggestion - also add a review of client satisfaction surveys
documents.recommended_action: Conduct a post-mortem review of the last 60 days of client communications to identify missed signals or warning signs. Schedule a transparency call with the client to clarify expectations for future offboarding and communication protocols.

documents.title: Suggestion: Jep - retention
documents.content: Provide proactive reassurance and personalized follow-up to Jep, explaining the situation was not performance-related and offering clear next steps for redeployment.
documents.summary: Provide proactive reassurance and personalized follow-up to Jep, explaining the situation was not performance-related and offering clear next steps for redeployment.
documents.issues: VA felt blind-sided by termination
documents.rationale: Job security concerns can lead to disengagement or attrition; past cases show that reassurance and clarity reduce churn risk and maintain VA trust.
documents.recommended_action: Provide proactive reassurance and personalized follow-up to Jep, explaining the situation was not performance-related and offering clear next steps for redeployment.

documents.title: Suggestion: Jep - contingency
documents.content: Fast-track Jeps profile to the recruitment team and prioritize matching with open client roles. Maintain regular check-ins until redeployed.
documents.summary: Fast-track Jeps profile to the recruitment team and prioritize matching with open client roles. Maintain regular check-ins until redeployed.
documents.issues: Potential for VA redeployment
documents.rationale: Quick redeployment after involuntary client loss is key to retaining experienced VAs, as seen in successful Outlier interventions.
documents.recommended_action: Fast-track Jeps profile to the recruitment team and prioritize matching with open client roles. Maintain regular check-ins until redeployed.

documents.title: Suggestion: Jep - communication
documents.content: Review and reinforce client offboarding protocols to ensure OA is notified before the VA, and that VAs are not left uninformed about major changes.
documents.summary: Review and reinforce client offboarding protocols to ensure OA is notified before the VA, and that VAs are not left uninformed about major changes.
documents.issues: Broken feedback loop between client and OA
documents.rationale: Feedback loop breakdowns have led to trust deficits in past cases; updating protocols prevents recurrence.
documents.recommended_action: Review and reinforce client offboarding protocols to ensure OA is notified before the VA, and that VAs are not left uninformed about major changes.

documents.title: Suggestion: Trisha - communication
documents.content: Switch to WhatsApp for urgent communications and conduct random personalized check-ins with Trisha to break silence and encourage engagement.
documents.summary: Switch to WhatsApp for urgent communications and conduct random personalized check-ins with Trisha to break silence and encourage engagement.
documents.issues: Non-responsiveness and low meeting participation
documents.rationale: Past Outlier meetings show silence is a high churn risk; personalized outreach improves VA responsiveness.
documents.recommended_action: Switch to WhatsApp for urgent communications and conduct random personalized check-ins with Trisha to break silence and encourage engagement.

documents.title: Suggestion: Trisha - reliability
documents.content: Schedule a technical audit and provide support to resolve computer and connection issues. Document any recurring problems.
documents.summary: Schedule a technical audit and provide support to resolve computer and connection issues. Document any recurring problems.
documents.issues: Technical/equipment reliability concerns
documents.rationale: Unresolved technical issues have led to MIA patterns in previous cases; proactive support prevents escalation.
documents.recommended_action: Schedule a technical audit and provide support to resolve computer and connection issues. Document any recurring problems.

documents.title: Suggestion: Trisha - visibility
documents.content: Implement daily SOD/EOD reporting for Trisha and coach her on maintaining visibility with the client.
documents.summary: Implement daily SOD/EOD reporting for Trisha and coach her on maintaining visibility with the client.
documents.issues: Lack of structured visibility to client
documents.rationale: Clients often assume VA inactivity without updates; structured reporting has reduced churn in similar cases.
documents.recommended_action: Implement daily SOD/EOD reporting for Trisha and coach her on maintaining visibility with the client.

documents.title: Suggestion: Trisha - performance
documents.content: Review action items from previous check-ins and set clear, measurable goals for Trisha. Pair with a mentor if stagnation continues.
documents.summary: Review action items from previous check-ins and set clear, measurable goals for Trisha. Pair with a mentor if stagnation continues.
documents.issues: No progress from coaching sessions
documents.rationale: Regular progress reviews and mentorship have improved outcomes for VAs with similar patterns.
documents.recommended_action: Review action items from previous check-ins and set clear, measurable goals for Trisha. Pair with a mentor if stagnation continues.

documents.title: Suggestion: Trisha - onboarding
documents.content: Increase check-in frequency to weekly for the next month to monitor engagement and address issues early.
documents.summary: Increase check-in frequency to weekly for the next month to monitor engagement and address issues early.
documents.issues: Infrequent check-ins (over 3 weeks gap)
documents.rationale: First 30-60 days are predictive; intensive monitoring reduces risk of disengagement and surprise churn.
documents.recommended_action: Increase check-in frequency to weekly for the next month to monitor engagement and address issues early.

documents.title: Suggestion: Katie - workload|compensation|retention
documents.content: Document the original scope and current expectations. Schedule an alignment call with the client to clarify hours, output expectations, and compensation. If scope expansion is permanent, request a formal adjustment.
documents.summary: Document the original scope and current expectations. Schedule an alignment call with the client to clarify hours, output expectations, and compensation. If scope expansion is permanent, request a formal adjustment.
documents.issues: Task scope expansion without formal acknowledgment or compensation discussion
documents.rationale: Unmanaged scope creep is a top churn driver. Past Outlier cases show that formalizing changes and discussing compensation early prevents disengagement and surprise resignations.
documents.recommended_action: Document the original scope and current expectations. Schedule an alignment call with the client to clarify hours, output expectations, and compensation. If scope expansion is permanent, request a formal adjustment.

documents.title: Suggestion: Katie - retention|performance|welfare
documents.content: Conduct a welfare check-in focused on support, not performance. Offer resources or peer support. Encourage honest feedback and clarify that catching up is expected, not a negative.
documents.summary: Conduct a welfare check-in focused on support, not performance. Offer resources or peer support. Encourage honest feedback and clarify that catching up is expected, not a negative.
documents.issues: VA mild overwhelm and neutral feedback period
documents.rationale: Similar cases (e.g., Anne Q2 2023) show that proactive support during 'catch-up' periods increases retention and improves feedback scores.
documents.recommended_action: Conduct a welfare check-in focused on support, not performance. Offer resources or peer support. Encourage honest feedback and clarify that catching up is expected, not a negative.

documents.title: Suggestion: Katie - visibility|client_relationship|performance
documents.content: Implement structured SOD/EOD reporting with templates and reminders. Coach VA on best practices and monitor for 2 weeks. Escalate if client still reports lack of visibility.
documents.summary: Implement structured SOD/EOD reporting with templates and reminders. Coach VA on best practices and monitor for 2 weeks. Escalate if client still reports lack of visibility.
documents.issues: Visibility/SOD-EOD reporting inconsistency
documents.rationale: Past Outlier meetings confirm that clients often equate silence with inactivity. Consistent visibility reporting is a low-effort, high-impact retention lever.
documents.recommended_action: Implement structured SOD/EOD reporting with templates and reminders. Coach VA on best practices and monitor for 2 weeks. Escalate if client still reports lack of visibility.

documents.title: Suggestion: Katie - client_relationship|contingency
documents.content: Monitor for changes in task flow, communication patterns, or feedback. Prepare a contingency plan if further restructuring impacts VA's role. Brief VA on possible changes to reduce uncertainty.
documents.summary: Monitor for changes in task flow, communication patterns, or feedback. Prepare a contingency plan if further restructuring impacts VA's role. Brief VA on possible changes to reduce uncertainty.
documents.issues: Client-side restructuring and role transition
documents.rationale: Internal client changes have led to surprise cancellations in past cases (e.g., Q1 2024). Early detection and communication reduce risk.
documents.recommended_action: Monitor for changes in task flow, communication patterns, or feedback. Prepare a contingency plan if further restructuring impacts VA's role. Brief VA on possible changes to reduce uncertainty.

documents.title: Suggestion: Jamaica - workload
documents.content: Document the original vs. current task scope and request an alignment call with the client to clarify expectations and discuss possible compensation or support adjustments if the expanded scope is permanent.
documents.summary: Document the original vs. current task scope and request an alignment call with the client to clarify expectations and discuss possible compensation or support adjustments if the expanded scope is permanent.
documents.issues: Task scope expanded significantly beyond original expectations (scope creep).
documents.rationale: Past Outlier meetings show that unaddressed scope creep leads to burnout and churn; early documentation and client alignment prevent escalation.
documents.recommended_action: Document the original vs. current task scope and request an alignment call with the client to clarify expectations and discuss possible compensation or support adjustments if the expanded scope is permanent.

documents.summary: Maintain transparent communication with the client about Stephas preferences and limits. Proactively discuss future staffing needs to avoid surprises.
documents.issues: Potential client resistance to full-time conversion.
documents.rationale: Past churn events have occurred when clients felt blind-sided by VA departures or role changes. Early, honest dialogue builds trust and allows for proactive planning.
documents.recommended_action: Maintain transparent communication with the client about Stephas preferences and limits. Proactively discuss future staffing needs to avoid surprises.

documents.title: Suggestion: Stepha - reliability
documents.content: Clarify Stephas availability and ensure her schedule aligns with client needs. If risk of divided attention is high, consider contract adjustment or backup VA.
documents.summary: Clarify Stephas availability and ensure her schedule aligns with client needs. If risk of divided attention is high, consider contract adjustment or backup VA.
documents.issues: VA juggling multiple jobs.
documents.rationale: VAs with multiple jobs are at higher risk of MIA or performance drops. Setting clear boundaries and expectations mitigates risk.
documents.recommended_action: Clarify Stephas availability and ensure her schedule aligns with client needs. If risk of divided attention is high, consider contract adjustment or backup VA.

documents.title: Suggestion: Marie - workload
documents.content: Conduct a welfare check-in focused on emotional support and clarify that feeling overwhelmed is normal in the first 30 days. Offer to pair Marie with a mentor or buddy who has navigated similar onboarding challenges.
documents.summary: Conduct a welfare check-in focused on emotional support and clarify that feeling overwhelmed is normal in the first 30 days. Offer to pair Marie with a mentor or buddy who has navigated similar onboarding challenges.
documents.issues: Marie feels overwhelmed by the complexity of the new system and training.
documents.rationale: Past Outlier meetings show that early overwhelm, if unaddressed, can lead to disengagement or churn. Welfare check-ins and peer support reduce risk.
documents.recommended_action: Conduct a welfare check-in focused on emotional support and clarify that feeling overwhelmed is normal in the first 30 days. Offer to pair Marie with a mentor or buddy who has navigated similar onboarding challenges.

documents.title: Suggestion: Marie - workload
documents.content: Document the original job scope and compare it to current tasks. Schedule an alignment call with the client to clarify expectations and discuss whether compensation or support adjustments are needed if the expanded scope becomes permanent.
documents.summary: Document the original job scope and compare it to current tasks. Schedule an alignment call with the client to clarify expectations and discuss whether compensation or support adjustments are needed if the expanded scope becomes permanent.
documents.issues: Task scope is expanding without clear documentation or acknowledgment.
documents.rationale: Scope creep is a common churn driver. Transparent documentation and alignment calls have prevented burnout and turnover in similar cases.
documents.recommended_action: Document the original job scope and compare it to current tasks. Schedule an alignment call with the client to clarify expectations and discuss whether compensation or support adjustments are needed if the expanded scope becomes permanent.

documents.title: Suggestion: Marie - onboarding
documents.content: Implement daily SOD/EOD check-ins for the next 2 weeks, with clear written expectations and feedback. Provide a template for goal-setting and progress tracking.
documents.summary: Implement daily SOD/EOD check-ins for the next 2 weeks, with clear written expectations and feedback. Provide a template for goal-setting and progress tracking.
documents.issues: Early-stage ambiguity in goals and action plans.
documents.rationale: Structured daily check-ins and clear goal templates have improved engagement and reduced early attrition in the first 30 days.
documents.recommended_action: Implement daily SOD/EOD check-ins for the next 2 weeks, with clear written expectations and feedback. Provide a template for goal-setting and progress tracking.

documents.title: Suggestion: Marie - retention
documents.content: Monitor Marie's engagement and well-being closely for the next 2-3 weeks. If signs of disengagement or continued overwhelm appear, consider reassignment or additional support.
documents.summary: Monitor Marie's engagement and well-being closely for the next 2-3 weeks. If signs of disengagement or continued overwhelm appear, consider reassignment or additional support.
documents.issues: Potential for low engagement if overwhelm persists.
documents.rationale: First 30 days are predictive of long-term retention. Early intervention is key.
documents.recommended_action: Monitor Marie's engagement and well-being closely for the next 2-3 weeks. If signs of disengagement or continued overwhelm appear, consider reassignment or additional support.

documents.title: Suggestion: Marie - reliability|contingency
documents.content: Initiate alternative contact via WhatsApp, phone, and emergency contact. Escalate internally if no response within 24h. Prepare replacement candidate if no contact within 48h.
documents.summary: Initiate alternative contact via WhatsApp, phone, and emergency contact. Escalate internally if no response within 24h. Prepare replacement candidate if no contact within 48h.
documents.issues: VA missing in action (MIA) for scheduled check-in.
documents.rationale: Past Outlier meetings show MIA patterns require urgent escalation to prevent client surprise cancellations and maintain service continuity.
documents.recommended_action: Initiate alternative contact via WhatsApp, phone, and emergency contact. Escalate internally if no response within 24h. Prepare replacement candidate if no contact within 48h.

documents.title: Suggestion: Marie - visibility|communication
documents.content: Implement structured daily SOD/EOD reporting for Marie. Coach on importance of visibility and provide templates for quick updates.
documents.summary: Implement structured daily SOD/EOD reporting for Marie. Coach on importance of visibility and provide templates for quick updates.
documents.issues: Lack of visibility to client (no SOD/EOD or updates).
documents.rationale: Clients often assume VAs are inactive without regular updates; visibility is critical for perceived value and retention.
documents.recommended_action: Implement structured daily SOD/EOD reporting for Marie. Coach on importance of visibility and provide templates for quick updates.

documents.issues: Potential breakdown in feedback loop and engagement.
documents.rationale: Past cases show that clients who feel blind-sided are more likely to churn; proactive communication can prevent escalation.
documents.recommended_action: Schedule a transparency call with client to clarify current VA status, reassure them, and rebuild trust through over-communication for next 30 days.
